question:
Identify one or more layers of the OSI model that carry out the following responsibilities and explain them in detail:     i) Transmission of bit stream across physical medium.
ii) Defines Frames                                                                            iii)Error correction and retransmission.                                         iv) Reliable Process-to-process message delivery.
v) Route selection.
vi) Provides user services such as e-mail and file transfer.
Compare and contrast star and mesh topologies using suitable examples.

Assume that processing delay, queuing delay and control overhead-bits are ignored. Consider the message size as 30,000 bits, the propagation time is 10ms per hop, packet length is 1000 bits, transmission rate per hop is 10000 bps and call set-up time is 2ms.Find the total time for both the circuit and packet switching networks when number of intermediate nodes as (i) 2, (ii) 5, (iii) 10, (iv) 50, (v) 100. Also, comment on the network performance in terms of the total delay in both the switching networks when the number of intermediate nodes increases

Consider an Internet application running on two Internet hosts, Host1 and Host2, which are communicating using a path through router R. Assume that the average service time (queuing and processing delay) at R is 15 ms, packets are 6,000 bits long and the propagation delay between Hostl and Host2 is 250ms. Also, ignore the control overhead.

Design PEAS for the following artificial intelligent agents.
i) Taxi driver agent 
ii) Automated robot in a manufacturing plant.          
iii) Playing soccer 
iv) Bidding an item on an auction 
v) Shopping for used AI books on the Internet

Consider the project developed by Google, codenamed Waymo. Waymo has 
successfully deployed self-driving cars with advanced sensors and implemented 
AI-based model algorithms in their decision-making process. These 
autonomous vehicles navigate the roads, making decisions based on percept 
history and real-time sensory input Ã¯Â¿Â½ the ability to make informed decisions 
based on historical data and real-time perceptual input received from the 
environments. Identify the most suitable model and explain how it fits this 
scenario where a decision has been made based on the perception of events that 
happened.

a) Suppose a genetic algorithm uses chromosomes of the form x = abcdefgh 
with a fixed length of eight genes. Each gene can be any digit between 0 
and 9. Let the fitness of individual x be calculated as: 
 f(x)=(a+b)-(c+d)+(e+f)-(g+h)
and let the initial population consist of four individuals with the following 
chromosomes: 
x1 = 6 5 4 1 3 5 3 2,
x2 = 8 7 1 2 6 6 0 1 ,
x3 = 2 3 9 2 1 2 8 5 ,
x4 = 4 1 8 5 2 0 9 4 
 
Evaluate each individual's fitness, showing all your workings and arrange 
them in order with the fittest first and the least fit last.
b) With a neat sketch of the hill-climbing algorithm's state-space landscape, 
explain why the hill-climbing search gets struck. List the variants of the hill 
climbing algorithm and describe how they overcome this problem

You are given with five different tasks like  
(i) Crossword puzzle 
(ii) N Queens Problem
(iii)  Tower of Hanoi 
(iv) Ludo 
List the PEAS description and the properties for the given tasks to their 
environment characteristics with suitable justification.

A taxi company wants to optimize its drivers' routes to reduce fuel 
consumption, minimize travel time, and enhance customer satisfaction. List 
the challenges and plans in developing an AI system for a real-time route 
optimization system that assists drivers in selecting the most efficient routes 
while considering dynamic factors like traffic, road conditions, toll plazas 
and weather conditions? Discuss with diagram the most suitable type of 
agent that can be used for this type of system.

Show that hill-climbing approach suffers from local optima in solving a 
problem. Use a global heuristic function to solve the same problem to reach 
the goal state.

A manufacturing plant aims to create an optimal production schedule
that reduces production time and efficiently utilizes resources. Discuss
how hill climbing could be applied to determine a feasible schedule,
highlighting potential obstacles. Also, illustrate how simulated
annealing can be used to overcome suboptimal solutions and achieve a
better schedule.

b) Explain the following (1) Model based Agent (2) Goal based agent

An Al agent is supposed to manage the energy consumption of a smart home. The agent's objective is to minimize the electricity bill while ensuring the residents' comfort. It has access to weather forecasts, real-time electricity pricing from the grid, and sensors in each room (temperature, occupancy). It can control the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) system, the smart lighting, and high-consumption appliances like the dishwasher and washing machine.
What is the correct PEAS categorization for this agent? Classify this task environment according to the following properties- Deterministic vs. Stochastic, Static vs. Dynamic, and Episodic vs. Sequential, and briefly justify your choices. What strategy should the agent adopt to effectively balance cost minimization with maintaining comfort?

A company wants to design a network for its new office building that spans four floors. The IT team needs to connect various departments such as finance, HR, and engineering located on different floors. The network must support high-speed internet access, secure communications, and the ability to handle large amounts of data being transferred within the office.
The following requirements must be met.
a) Each department should have its own dedicated segment to reduce traffic congestion.
b) The network should be scalable to accommodate future expansions.
c) Security is important, so there must be provisions for isolating department and preventing unauthorized access to data.
d) A wireless network should cover common areas like the lobby and cafeteria.
Compare and contrast Circuit Switching and packet Switching

A defence organization is planning to have the network built for their newly constructed office. There are 3 scientists working on confidential projects. Each scientist has a team of 5 engineers. Sketch a suitable topology with justification.
A company is hiring freshers to work on the Application layer and Transport layer. Identify any 4 protocols with their purpose, which the candidate has to be familiar to be eligible for the job.

a) In a wireless communication system, a sensor node is transmitting temperature data of 7 bits to a base station. To ensure reliable transmission, Hamming code with even parity is applied to each temperature data. The data received on the receiving end is 01010111101. Identify any error and mention the steps to correct it.
topic: ERROR DETECTION AND CORRECTION / HAMMING CODES

question:
a) The data captured from Wireshark tool is given below. Show the IPv4 header format with values given.
DX4500004da548000080110000c0a82b7fc0a82b01
b) Analyse if the data is fragmented or corrupted with justification.

A network uses the 172.12.0.0 class B address. There is a requirement to support 459 hosts per subnet, while accommodating the maximum number of subnets.
Construct the subnet mask and the IP layout for 4 valid subnets with details of the first address, range of address and the broadcast address.
Differentiate closed loop and open loop congestion control by quoting 2 mechanisms from each method.

a) Assuming N stations are present in pure Aloha Network, having a bandwidth of
56Kb/Sec find the value of N, assuming that each station sends data of size 1000
bits at an average interval of 100 sec.
b) X is working as a Business Development Lead in a leading MNC and keeps
traveling frequently. X is also given the task to attend online meetings even in transit.
An urgent meet was called for when X was about to board his flight and there was
a poor network in his mobile. X contacted the helpdesk requesting for internet
connection. Which IEEE standard would help to connect to the airlineÂs internet
service? Enumerate the architecture involved in connecting to the airlineÂs internet service.

a. Consider an IP packet with a length 4500 bytes that includes a 20-byte IPv4 header and a 40-byte TCP header. The packet is forwarded to an IPV4 router that supports a Maximum Transmission unit MTU of 600 bytes. Assume that the length of the header in all the outgoing fragments of this packet is 20 bytes. Assume that the
fragmentation offset value store in the first fragment is 0. What is the fragmentation offset stored in the third fragment?
b. A CEO of a company needs a privacy in maintaining the number of hosts for his company to the public network with a single IP address. What is the networking technology required for the above and explain the same?

Draw the sender and receiver windows for a system using Selective Repeat
ARQ (3-bits for sequence number), given the following:
i) Frame 0 is sent; frame 0 is acknowledged.
ii) Frame 1 and 2 are sent; frames 1 and 2 are acknowledged.
iii) Frame 3, 4 and 5 are sent; frame 4 is acknowledged; timer for frame 5
expires.
iv) Frame 5, 6 and 7 are sent; frames 4 through 7 are acknowledged
What is Data Abstraction? Explain about different views of data
List the types of Database users and discuss the roles of DBA

Design an EER diagram to capture the requirements of an e-commerce platform that sells products online. The platform should allow users to browse products, add them to their shopping carts, checkout, and track their orders. Every product has a unique ID, name, description, price, quantity in stock, and category. Categories represent different product groups (e.g., electronics, clothing, books). Products can be categorized into different types (e.g., books, electronics, and clothing). Every customer has a unique ID, name, email, address, and shipping information. Each order has a unique ID, customer ID, order date, shipping address, and total amount. Each order can have multiple items. An order item specifies the product ID, quantity, and price. Each order has associated payment information, including payment method, transaction ID, and payment status. Customers can leave reviews for products, including a rating and a text comment. The platform can offer promotions and discounts on products.
State any assumptions you have that affects your design. Clearly indicate primary keys and the cardinalities with which an entity participates in a relationship with a pair of (minimum, maximum) value.

Define conflict serializable, recoverable, cascadeless, and strict schedules.
For each of the following schedules, state which of the above mentioned properties
hold. Justify your answer.
a) S: R1(X), W2(X), W1(X), A2, C1
b) S2: R1(X), W2(X), W1(X), C2, C1
c)S3: R1(X), R2(X), W1(X), C1, W2(X), C2
d) S4:  W 1(X), R2(X), W1(X) ,C2,A1
e) S5: W1(X), R2(Y)C1, C2
f) S6:  R1(X), R2(X),C1,W2(X),C2

Given a large-scale e-commerce application that requires high availability, low latency, and the ability to handle massive amounts of transactional data, which NoSQL database types would be most suitable? Justify your answer with specific scenarios to illustrate the key considerations. Discuss why other NoSQL types might not be suitable.

Consider a B+-tree of order three. Show the results of entering one by one the keys that are three letter strings: (era, ban, bat, kin, day, log, rye, max, won, ace, ado, bug, cop, gas, let, fax) (in that order) to an initially empty 8+-tree. Assume that you use lexicographic ordering to compare the strings. Show the state of the tree after every 4 insertions.

A relation R has attributes A, B, C, D, E, and satisfies the following FDs:
ABC
BD
CDE
EA
a) Show that (A, B, C) and (A, D, E) are a lossless decomposition of R.
b) Show that (A, B, C) and (C, D, E) are not a lossless decomposition of R.
c) Show that (A, B, C) and (A, D, E) are not a dependency preserving decomposition of R.

1. Given a relation schema R (ABCDE) with a set of FDs, let F (ABC, BCA, BCDE, EC). 
(i) Is the given relation present in the BCNF or not? If not then decompose into BCNF.

(ii) Is that the decomposed relation preserving the functional dependencies? If no then list the functional dependencies that are not preserved and state the reason.

A sequential file is ordered on EmployeeID. The file has 1,00,000 records, block size 1,000 bytes, record size 100 bytes. (i)
Determine the number of records that can be stored in a single block and calculate the total number of blocks required to store the entire file of records.
(ii) If 2,000 new employee records are inserted randomly, estimate the numbers of block splits or reorganizations are expected?
(iii) Suppose a primary index is built with one index entry per block. Compute the number of index blocks required. Assume index entry size 10 bytes for key and 4 bytes for pointer.
(iv) Suggest an alternative file organization to reduce insertion cost, and justify the answer.

Consider the following schedules for an e-commerce website. The
transactions indicate the consumers performing one of the following
actions: Cart Service (adding products to the cart), Purchase service,
Payment service and shipping service. The schedules S1 and S2 show
the different ways these transactions are interleaved. Of these
schedules, identify the schedule that can be called an equivalent to a
serial schedule of transactions. Explain and justify your answer.
S1: R2(X)R3(X)W3(X)R1(X)W1(X)R2(Y)W2(Y)R2(Z)R4(Y)R4(X)
S2-> R1(X)W1(X)R4(Z)W4(X)R2(X)R3(Y)R3(Z)W3(Z)R1(Z)W2(X)

(ii) Shows the form of the B-tree after each operation of the sequence Insert 9, 10,
(iii)3) Shows the form of the B-tree after each operation of the sequence Delete 19, 23;

Consider the transactions T1, T2, and 13 and the schedules SI and S2 given below.
T1: rl(A); r1(C); w1(A); w1(C)
T2: 12(B); r2(C); w2(C)
T3: r3(B); 13(A); w3(B)
S1: r1(A); r3(B); 13(A); r2(B); r2(C); w3(B); w2(C); r1(C); w1(A); w1(C)
S2: r 1(A); r3(B); r2(B); r3(A); r1(C); r2(C); w3(B); w1(A); w2(C); w1(C)
Check whether the given Schedules S1 or S2 are conflict serializable or not?
Give justification to your answer with neat explanation.

Explain the ProducerÂConsumer problem and implement a solution using semaphores or monitors.
Discuss how deadlock can occur if semaphore usage is incorrect.

Differentiate between internal and external fragmentation.
Given a memory of 100 MB divided into partitions of 20 MB each, and processes requiring 15, 25, 10, and 30 MB respectively Â calculate wasted memory for First Fit, Best Fit, and Worst Fit strategies.

What is demand paging?
Given the reference string 1, 2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 3 page frames, compute the number of page faults using FIFO and LRU algorithms.

Describe different disk scheduling algorithms (FCFS, SSTF, SCAN, C-SCAN).
Given the disk queue request sequence: 82, 170, 43, 140, 24, 16, 190 with head at 50, calculate the total seek time for each algorithm assuming a seek rate of 1 ms per track.

Explain how system calls act as the interface between user programs and the OS kernel.
Write a simple C program to demonstrate the use of fork() and exec() system calls, and describe what happens in memory during their execution.

A system has 1,000 instructions per second.
A memory access takes 1 ?s. A page fault takes 5 ms to handle.
If 0.1% of memory accesses cause page faults, compute the Effective Access Time (EAT).
Then discuss how TLB (Translation Lookaside Buffer) improves this performance if TLB hit ratio = 90% and TLB access time = 0.1 ?s.

A disk rotates at 7200 RPM and has 200 tracks. Average seek time is 8 ms.
If a read request arrives for track 150 while the head is at track 50, calculate:

1)Seek time

2)Rotational latency

Total average access time
Compare results for SSTF and SCAN assuming uniform request distribution.

A system has 4 page frames and uses the Optimal Page Replacement algorithm.
Given the reference string:
7, 0, 1, 2, 0, 3, 0, 4, 2, 3, 0, 3, 2
Compute the number of page faults.
Then compare results with LRU and Clock (Second Chance) algorithms.

Modern multicore kernels (like Linux) use spinlocks and mutexes differently in kernel-space.

(a) Explain why spinlocks are preferred in certain kernel contexts, and why they must not be held during sleep or I/O operations.
(b) Given a 16-core system running critical sections protected by a single spinlock, each section taking 1 ?s, and a contention rate of 70%, estimate:

The expected waiting time per core, and

How performance scales if contention increases to 90%.

(c) Propose one design to reduce contention (e.g., using lock striping, RCU, or per-CPU data).

n a virtualized system (using a Type-1 hypervisor), guest OSes believe they manage their own page tables, but the hypervisor maintains shadow page tables.

(a) Explain how shadow page tables work and the role of Extended Page Tables (EPT/NPT) in hardware-assisted virtualization.
(b) Derive the effective memory access time when:

Each memory access requires a guest page table lookup (2 memory references)

Each guest lookup triggers a host-level page translation (2 more memory references)

TLB hit ratio = 95%, TLB access time = 5 ns, and memory access = 100 ns

(c) Compare this to nested paging performance and suggest optimizations used in modern CPUs.

a distributed database system with three sites (S1, S2, S3), processes at each site can request resources at others.
Each site maintains its own Wait-For Graph (WFG), and periodically exchanges partial WFGs to detect cycles.

(a) Explain how distributed deadlock detection using edge-chasing works.
(b) Show an example where a false deadlock is detected due to message delay.
(c) Propose a timestamp-based resolution algorithm to avoid false positives.
(d) Analyze the message complexity of your solution in terms of number of sites (N) and edges (E).

Modern operating systems like seL4 and Capsicum implement capability-based security rather than traditional ACLs.

(a) Explain how capabilities enforce fine-grained access control compared to ACLs.
(b) Design a capability revocation protocol that allows secure, immediate revocation of privileges without halting processes.
(c) Prove that your mechanism prevents confused deputy attacks.
(d) Discuss the trade-off between flexibility and performance in capability-based systems.

ompare monolithic, microkernel, and hybrid kernel architectures.
Design a microkernel message-passing structure for handling inter-process communication (IPC) and analyze its performance overhead versus a system call trap.

In a SMP (Symmetric Multiprocessing) system with 4 CPUs, 10 tasks are ready, each with known burst times.
Explain how load balancing is achieved using work stealing and processor affinity.
Analyze what happens if task migration cost = 2 ms and average task execution time = 5 ms.

Explain the lifecycle of an EC2 instance.
How does AWS handle instance states like pending, running, stopping, stopped, and terminated?
Also, differentiate between EBS-backed and Instance-store-backed instances.

You have a web application hosted on EC2 instances behind an Application Load Balancer (ALB).
Describe how Auto Scaling Groups (ASG) maintain fault tolerance and high availability.
How would you configure scaling policies for unpredictable traffic spikes?

Explain how AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) enforces principle of least privilege.

You need:

2 public subnets

2 private subnets
Each in a different Availability Zone.

Under what circumstances is Lambda a poor choice?

Explain how Elastic IP addresses work in EC2.
What happens when you associate an Elastic IP with a stopped instance and then start a new one with the same IP?

You have an EC2 instance that loses its data every time you stop it.
What kind of storage is it using, and how can you prevent this behavior?

Explain the differences between Application Load Balancer (ALB), Network Load Balancer (NLB), and Classic Load Balancer (CLB).
Which would you use for WebSocket connections and why?

In an Auto Scaling Group, you set the desired capacity to 4.
If one instance becomes unhealthy, what happens next?
How does AWS determine Âunhealthy,Â and how is it replaced?

A developer accidentally granted s3:* permission to all users.
Explain the risk, and how would you use IAM Access Analyzer to detect and fix such over-permissive policies?

You have two EC2 instances in different VPCs that need to communicate securely.
Explain VPC Peering and Transit Gateway.
Which is better for many-to-many communication and why?

Give one example use case for each.

Explain the Multi-AZ deployment in Amazon RDS.
How does it ensure high availability and automatic failover?

You have an RDS MySQL instance running in a single AZ.
If the AZ goes down, what happens to your database?
What would you change to make your RDS setup more fault-tolerant?

Describe the provisioned throughput and on-demand capacity modes in DynamoDB.
What happens if a table in provisioned mode receives more requests than the defined write capacity units (WCUs)?
What is the difference between stack and queue in terms of data access order?

An online food delivery platform stores restaurant distances in a graph. The system must recommend nearest available outlet quickly. Propose a graph traversal or shortest path strategy, explain time complexity, and evaluate performance if number of restaurants increases drastically.

A media streaming service caches frequently accessed movies to improve performance. Explain how heap data structure can be used to maintain a priority queue of most-watched items, describe insertion and deletion complexity, and analyze behavior under heavy load.

A navigation system tracks city routes as weighted graphs. Explain how Dijkstraâs algorithm would determine shortest path, discuss when Bellman-Ford is preferred, and analyze worst-case runtime in large city networks.

With the help of interrupt programming, develop an ALP of 8051 microcontrollers to perform
the following tasks; continuously get numeric data from P0 and send it to P1. If the data is even,
serially send it through port P2 with a baud rate of 19200. Otherwise, the data will be sent

A football stadium is designed with a seating capacity of precisely 1000 persons. It is assumed
that there is just one entry and exit gate accessible within the stadium. The entry gate is
configured so that whenever a person enters a stadium, a high-to-low pulse will be generated and
that will be given to the port3.4 of the 8051 microcontroller. The stepper motor regulates the
opening and shutting of the entry gate. To open/close the entry gate, send a logic 1/logic 0 to
10
port0.5 of the 8051 microcontroller, which connects to the stepper motor. Develop an ALP of
8051 that counts and allows maximum up to 1000 persons and closes the gate after that
irrespective of persons leaving from the exit gate. Use the mode 2 timer programming
